headline.print_headline: A Trainer to the Stars Who’s a Star-to-Be

docs.lead_paragraph: Housing plans for active retirees take into account the desire to be near urban centers and the wish to live at home as long as possible.

headline.main: For Modern Retirees, There’s No Place Like Home
headline.print_headline: For Modern Retirees, There’s No Place Like Home

docs.abstract: Housing plans for active retirees take into account the desire to stay in one's home as long as possible and the interest in living in big-city neighborhoods or suburban downtowns; cities are building new neighborhood infrastructure--transit lines, public markets, parks and denser housing--that is accessible without driving.
docs.snippet: Housing plans for active retirees take into account the desire to be near urban centers and the wish to live at home as long as possible.

docs.lead_paragraph: In sharp contrast to earlier generations, many people retire and then unretire, or continue working well after they were supposed to have retired.

headline.seo: Pushing Back Retirement, and Not Always for Money
headline.main: Pushing Back Retirement, and Not Always for Money
headline.print_headline: In and Out, Off and On

docs.abstract: Many people today, in sharp contrast to earlier generations, retire and then unretire by taking part-time jobs or becoming entrepreneurs, or continue working well after they were supposed to have retired; trend may be fueled by fact that many more Americans are living into their late 80s and 90s, and many of them are outliving their retirement savings.
docs.snippet: In sharp contrast to earlier generations, many people retire and then unretire, or continue working well after they were supposed to have retired.

docs.lead_paragraph: Representative Paul D. Ryan’s plan to cut spending was unveiled on Tuesday as Democrats circulated the outlines of their budget, repudiating many aspects of the Republican effort.

headline.main: 2 Parties’ Budgets Show Big Rift as G.O.P. Renews 2012 Proposals
headline.print_headline: 2 Parties’ Budgets Show Big Rift As G.O.P. Renews 2012 Proposals

docs.abstract: Senate Democrats and House Republicans outline vastly divergent approaches to shoring up government finances, reminder of how far part parties remain on fiscal policy despite agreement that compromise is possible; Republican proposal, led by Rep Paul Ryan, relies heavily on policies that attracted heavy criticism during 2012 presidential campaign.
docs.snippet: Representative Paul D. Ryan’s plan to cut spending was unveiled on Tuesday as Democrats circulated the outlines of their budget, repudiating many aspects of the Republican effort.

byline.contributor: Mark Landler and Jada F. Smith contributed reporting.
byline.original: By JEREMY W. PETERS and JONATHAN WEISMAN

docs.lead_paragraph:
The New York Times article on a judge’s ruling on Monday striking down the city’s impending limits on large sugary drinks drew more than 1,300 comments from readers representing a wide range of regulatory philosophies. Here are some of them. A few have been condensed slightly. 

 
This is one time when common sense won out. Yes, too much sugar is bad, but the law was dumb. Anyone who wanted more soda could just refill their cup, especially in all those fast-food restaurants with self-service soda machines, which is most of them. The law also created a maze of rules and applied only to specific places serving specific kinds of choices, but not the choice to drink as much soda or have as much sugar as you wanted. — Carmela Sanford, Niagara Falls, N.Y.

headline.main: Mixed Reviews For a Judge’s Ruling

headline.main: A Bumpy Road to a Soda Ban

docs.abstract: Many public health experts support efforts to ban the sale of large sugary drinks but note that, as with efforts to curb tobacco or require seat belt use, the process will take some time.
